Award.AwardTitle: Approximating Large Contests and other Auction-Like Games: a Mechanism Design Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research in game theory. The PIs study strategic situations using mathematical models, with an emphasis on certain types of auctions. They establish that the equilibria of such auction-like games converge, as the number of players grows, to the outcomes of some inventive-compatible and individually rational single-agent mechanisms. This enables the use of tools developed for mechanism design to approximate and study the equilibria of auction-like games with a large number of players. The research team uses this idea to study contests, uniform price auctions, and double auctions.

There are many kinds of contests with large numbers of participants. University admissions, promotions in large corporations, and prizes for outstanding accomplishments are all examples. This project will give us new tools to determine how differences in contest rules affect the outcomes of the contest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The authors developed tractable methods for studying contests with a large number of contestants and prizes. The main idea was to use as approximate predictions of contest outcomes the predicted outcomes of some single-agent mechanisms. This enabled the use of a large set of tools developed in mechanism design for studying contests. The authors believe that their approximate methods will also turn out useful in exploring other large “auction-like” environments.
The developed methods apply to such contests as college admissions, competitions for research grants, salesmen competitions, and large sport events such as street marathons. The authors primarily focused on the first two of these applications.
The authors qualitatively and quantitatively characterized prize structures that maximize some contest designers’ objectives, given a limited prize budget at the designer’s disposal. Examples of such objectives include contestants’ aggregate performance, or the aggregate performance of a top fraction of the contestants. For these settings, a main takeaway from the project is that awarding numerous prizes whose values gradually decline with contestants’ ranking is optimal when contestants are risk averse and have a convex cost of performance.
This suggests, for example, that if the NSF is interested in increasing the overall broader impacts of proposals, it should adopt a wider spectrum of award sizes, ranging from small to large, than it currently appears to have in some disciplines (e.g., in economics). Numerous prizes whose values gradually decline also seem optimal in other contests such as mathematics olympiads or salesman competitions.
The authors also demonstrate in the context of college admissions that reducing the information released to colleges about students’ performance can improve students’ welfare in a Pareto sense. The improvement is particularly intuitive, and well documented, for top students. And the reduction of released information can be achieved by modifying the disclosure policies of various standardized tests (such as ACT and SAT), or by reducing the number of AP classes that students are allowed to take.
These Pareto-improving policies have been investigated as a theoretical possibility, but the authors have already initiated a continuation project to provide an empirical foundation for the use of these policies.
